item.title: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rises 0.3% to 7,848.3 points in early trade
item.description:
Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rises 0.3% to 7,848.3 points in early trade

The Australian stock market opened the week on a positive note, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.3% to 7,848.3 points in early trade [1]. This upward trend is not an isolated incident, as the index has displayed resilience in the face of global economic uncertainties.

Launched in 2000, the S&P/ASX 200 index replaced the All Ordinaries as Australia's primary investment benchmark [1]. It represents a high percentage of the Australian stock market, making it an accurate reflection of the overall market performance. The index's dual function includes providing a benchmark for the stock market and offering a highly liquid and tradable index for institutional investors [1].

The importance of inclusion in the ASX 200 cannot be overstated. Listed companies place significant emphasis on their presence in the index, as it generates institutional interest, encourages investment, and often attracts research from stockbroking firms and analysts [1].

The S&P/ASX 200 index has displayed impressive returns since its inception, with an average annual return of 3.86% excluding dividends and 8.26% including dividends [1]. This performance is a testament to the strength and resilience of the Australian stock market.

The index is rebalanced quarterly to maintain listing criteria and liquidity [1]. The most recent rebalance in December 2024 saw the addition of one company and the deletion of another.

Investors interested in tracking the performance of the S&P/ASX 200 can consider exchange-traded funds (ETFs) such as BetaShares A200, BetaShares Geared Australian Equity, and SPDR S&P/ASX 200 ESG [1]. These ETFs offer investors exposure to the Australian stock market while providing various investment strategies.

The S&P/ASX 200 index's upward trend in early trade is a positive sign for the Australian stock market. However, investors should remain vigilant and closely monitor global economic developments, as they can impact the performance of the Australian stock market.

References:
[1] Market Index. (n.d.). S&P/ASX 200 Index. Retrieved January 16, 2025, from https://www.marketindex.com.au/asx200

item.title: Kraken nears $1.5 billion deal for NinjaTrader, sources say
item.description:
Kraken nears $1.5 billion deal for NinjaTrader, sources say

In a recent blog post, Kraken co-CEO Arjun Sethi shared the exchange's impressive 2024 financial results. The company reported revenue of $1.5 billion, a 128% year-over-year increase, and adjusted EBITDA of $380 million. With clients entrusting the platform with $42.8 billion in assets and 2.5 million funded accounts, Kraken's average revenue per customer surpassed $2,000, a significant milestone for the industry [1].

Rumors have been circulating that Kraken is in talks to acquire NinjaTrader, a well-known trading platform for active traders. The potential deal is reportedly valued at around $1.5 billion [2]. If true, this acquisition would significantly expand Kraken's reach and offerings in the retail trading space.

Kraken, founded in 2011, has always been known for its focus on security, reliability, and accessibility. With a clear vision and a relentless focus on execution, the company has disproven the narrative that you need to raise billions to generate billions. Kraken's incredible tech platform has executed 2.5 billion trades since inception, with a 99.9% uptime and sub-2ms round trip latency [1].

The acquisition of NinjaTrader, if successful, would not be Kraken's first move in expanding its offerings. The company recently launched its own non-fungible token (NFT) platform, Kraken NFT, and has been exploring partnerships and integrations with other DeFi platforms.

As regulatory clarity continues to improve and industry tailwinds strengthen, Kraken is well-positioned for even greater growth. The potential acquisition of NinjaTrader would further solidify Kraken's position as a major player in the crypto and retail trading space.

References:
[1] Kraken. (2023, February 28). Kraken 2024 Financials. Retrieved from https://blog.kraken.com/news/kraken-2024-financials
[2] The Block. (2023, March 1). Kraken reportedly in talks to acquire NinjaTrader for $1.5 billion. Retrieved from https://www.theblock.co/latest/117843/kraken-reportedly-in-talks-to-acquire-ninjatrader-for-1-5-billion

item.title: US House Intel Panel to hold March 26 hearing on worldwide risks
item.description:
US House Intel Panel to hold March 26 hearing on worldwide risks

The US House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence (HPSCI) has announced a hearing for Wednesday, March 26, 2025, to examine the annual assessment of worldwide threats to the national security of the United States [1]. This open hearing will feature the Directors of various intelligence agencies, including the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI), Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI), National Security Agency (NSA), and Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) [1].

The global threat landscape is becoming increasingly complex, with various adversaries seeking to weaken alliances, undermine ways of life, and deteriorate readiness. These threats include the growing influence and investment of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in the Western Hemisphere, Iran's role as the largest state sponsor of terror, and Russia's aggression and irregular activities [1].

HPSCI Chairman Rick Crawford emphasized the importance of staying prepared in the face of these threats, stating, "An inability to connect the dots to ensure a robust national security posture is unacceptable" [1].

The hearing will take place at 1100 Longworth House Office Building, starting at 10:00 AM ET, and will be live-streamed on YouTube [1]. Press must be congressionally credentialed and RSVP by Tuesday, March 25, at 5:00 PM ET to attend the hearing [1].

HPSCI has a busy schedule, with several other closed and open hearings on topics such as FISA reform, China threats, special counsel John Durham updates, security clearance reform, and full committee hearings [2].

[1] https://intelligence.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=1509
[2] https://intelligence.house.gov/calendar/?CategoryID=0&EventTypeID=215

item.title: SPDR Gold Trust, the world's largest gold ETF, holdings increased by 2.01 tonnes to 909.28 tonnes.
item.description:
SPDR Gold Trust, the world's largest gold ETF, holdings increased by 2.01 tonnes to 909.28 tonnes.

The SPDR Gold Trust, the world's largest gold exchange-traded fund (ETF), has experienced a noteworthy increase in its holdings. According to recent data from financecharts.com and gold.org, the Trust now holds a total of 909.28 tonnes of gold, marking a 2.01 tonne addition since the previous report [1].

The SPDR Gold Trust, symbolized as GLD on the New York Stock Exchange Arca, is designed to track the price of gold, less the Trust's expenses. With an estimated expense ratio of 0.40%, the Trust offers investors a cost-effective means to invest in gold [3].

As of the latest data, the SPDR Gold Trust holds the majority of its gold reserves with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. serving as the gold custodian [3]. The Trust's increased holdings signify a growing demand for gold as an investment asset.

Physically-backed gold ETFs, such as the SPDR Gold Trust, have gained popularity among investors due to their role in diversifying investment portfolios. According to data from gold.org, gold ETFs accounted for approximately 2,800 tonnes of gold demand in 2020, with institutional and individual investors utilizing them as part of well-diversified investment strategies [2].

The SPDR Gold Trust's latest holdings increase further emphasizes the ongoing interest in gold as a safe-haven asset and a potential hedge against economic uncertainty.

[1] https://www.financecharts.com/stocks/GLD
[2] https://www.gold.org/goldhub/data/gold-etfs-holdings-and-flows
[3] https://www.spdrgoldshares.com/usa/key-information/
item.author: AInvest

item.title: Unilever seeks to dismiss Ben & Jerry's lawsuit accusing it of trying to dismantle ice cream maker's board and end its social activism, court filing shows
item.description:
Unilever seeks to dismiss Ben & Jerry's lawsuit accusing it of trying to dismantle ice cream maker's board and end its social activism, court filing shows

Unilever, the multinational consumer goods corporation, is currently embroiled in a lawsuit filed by its subsidiary, Ben & Jerry's, accusing the parent company of attempting to dismantle the ice cream maker's board and silence its social activism [1]. The dispute, which centers around the termination of David Stever, Ben & Jerry's CEO, has escalated, with Ben & Jerry's claiming that Unilever's actions were motivated by the CEO's commitment to the company's social mission rather than his job performance.

According to the complaint filed in federal court in Manhattan on March 19, 2025, Unilever informed the Ben & Jerry's board on March 3 that it intended to remove and replace Stever as CEO without the approval of an advisory board and against an agreement signed when the two companies merged in 2000 [1]. Ben & Jerry's argues that this action was a breach of the agreement, which allowed the ice cream company to maintain an independent board to oversee its brand and social activism.

The termination of Stever, who had been CEO since 2023, came after Ben & Jerry's outperformed Unilever's other ice cream brands in 2024, with sales growing faster than those of Magnum [1]. This success, coupled with Stever's support for the company's social mission, seems to have raised concerns within Unilever.

The ongoing legal battle between Unilever and Ben & Jerry's is not an isolated incident. In November 2024, Ben & Jerry's filed a lawsuit against its parent company, accusing Unilever of censorship and threats over the ice cream maker's efforts to express support for Palestinian refugees [1]. The lawsuit claimed that Unilever tried to dismantle the ice cream maker's independent board and prevent it from taking certain political stances.

The founders of Ben & Jerry's, Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, have long been known for their activism on social issues. Tensions between the two companies reached a boiling point in 2021, when Ben & Jerry's announced that it would stop selling its products in Israeli-occupied territories [1].

As the legal battle between Unilever and Ben & Jerry's unfolds, it raises questions about the balance between corporate governance and social activism. It remains to be seen how this dispute will be resolved and what implications it may have for other companies that embrace social activism.

References:
[1] "Ben & Jerry’s accused Unilever, its parent company, of firing its chief executive because he allowed the ice cream maker to speak out on political issues, court filing shows," The New York Times, March 19, 2025, https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/19/business/ben-and-jerrys-unilever-lawsuit-ceo.html

item.title: Zelensky: Trump did not exert pressure during call.
item.description:
Zelensky: Trump did not exert pressure during call.

As the tension between Ukraine and Russia continues to escalate, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky anticipates a call with his US counterpart, President Donald Trump, to discuss the details of potential next steps [1]. The call comes after Trump's conversation with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday, during which they reportedly agreed to a limited ceasefire aimed at halting attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure [1].

However, Zelensky's stance on the ceasefire remains cautious. He expressed his willingness to consider the latest offer but emphasized the need for US monitoring to ensure its effectiveness [1]. Zelensky has previously characterized Russia's demands for preconditions to a broader ceasefire as a stalling tactic, designed to improve Moscow's military and negotiating positions [1].

The mistrust between the two nations was further exemplified on Wednesday, as each side accused the other of attacks on their respective energy infrastructure [1]. The lack of trust raises concerns about the sustainability of any ceasefire agreement, particularly one that falls short of the more comprehensive 30-day truce previously proposed by Ukraine [1].

Trump's phone call with Putin is expected to take place between 13:00 and 15:00 GMT today, with discussions focusing on the "normalization" of US-Russian relations [2]. This development comes amidst increasing international pressure on both leaders to de-escalate the situation in Ukraine and prevent further damage to the region's infrastructure.

[1] New York Times. (2025, March 19). Zelensky: Trump did not exert pressure during call. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/19/world/europe/zelensky-trump-ukraine-russia-putin.html

[2] BBC News. (2025, March 19). Trump says he is 'very much' looking forward to Putin call over Ukraine. https://www.bbc.com/news/live/c3e4xzd8qq8t
item.author: AInvest

item.title: Zelensky to visit France next week.
item.description:
Zelensky to visit France next week.

In a delicate dance of diplomacy, French President Emmanuel Macron is set to visit both Ukraine and Russia next week [1]. Macron's visit comes amidst escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine, with the latter seeking security guarantees from the West against potential Russian aggression [1].

Macron's visit to Kyiv, scheduled for February 8, follows his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow on February 7 [1]. Macron aims to capitalize on the limited progress made during the "Normandy format" peace talks on Ukraine in Paris last month [1].

The French president's primary objective is to find a negotiated path towards de-escalating tensions over Ukraine [1]. He has emphasized the importance of discussing the conditions to reach strategic balance in Europe, in order to reduce tension on the ground and guarantee security on the continent [1].

Macron's visit to Ukraine is not without its challenges. The Kremlin has made clear that the priority of the talks will be Moscow's demands for security guarantees from the West [1]. However, Macron has signaled his intention to see what can be negotiated to reduce Russia's military build-up, thus helping to start defusing tensions [1].

It is essential to note that NATO will not get involved militarily in Ukraine [1]. Instead, diplomatic efforts are being made to address the situation and find a peaceful resolution.

Macron's visit to Ukraine and Russia is a testament to his commitment to finding a diplomatic solution to the ongoing tensions between the two countries. As the situation continues to evolve, it will be interesting to see what progress, if any, can be made during Macron's visits.

References:

[1] France 24. (2022, February 4). France's Macron to meet Putin and Zelensky in separate talks next week. https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20220204-france-s-macron-to-meet-putin-and-zelensky-in-separate-talks-next-week
item.author: AInvest

item.title: Zelensky: No additional demands for partial ceasefire.
item.description:
Zelensky: No additional demands for partial ceasefire.

In a recent development, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced his intention to hold talks with U.S. President Donald Trump following renewed Russian drone attacks on Ukrainian infrastructure despite a partial ceasefire agreement brokered by Washington [1]. This latest round of hostilities has raised questions about the durability of the truce and highlighted the challenges of achieving lasting peace between the two parties.

On Tuesday, Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to an immediate ceasefire focused on energy and infrastructure facilities [1]. However, the truce has proven fragile, with both sides reporting attacks on their respective territories in the hours following the Kremlin's pledge to halt assaults. Ukrainian authorities in Sumy reported damage to hospital buildings from Russian drone strikes overnight, while Kyiv officials claimed 18 residences, 20 townhouse apartments, and 19 vehicles were hit [1]. In response, Moscow accused Ukraine of launching a retaliatory drone attack on an oil depot in the Krasnodar region [1].

Despite these developments, Zelensky remains committed to a peaceful resolution, welcoming a planned prisoner exchange between the two countries as a potential trust-building measure [1]. However, he remains skeptical of broader Russian intentions and has dismissed Moscow's claims that the ceasefire applies solely to energy infrastructure. Instead, Zelensky has emphasized that any meaningful peace negotiations must address the underlying issues fueling the conflict [1].

With the situation in Ukraine continuing to evolve, the international community must remain vigilant and supportive of efforts to promote peace and stability in the region.

[1] https://www.btimesonline.com/articles/173355/20250319/zelensky-trump-to-discuss-next-steps-as-russia-ukraine-report-strikes-despite-ceasefire.htm

item.title: Sequoia Capital closes Washington D.C. office, disbands policy team.
item.description:
Sequoia Capital closes Washington D.C. office, disbands policy team.

Sequoia Capital, the esteemed venture capital firm renowned for backing category-defining companies such as Apple, Google, Cisco, and Snowflake, has recently made headlines by closing its Washington D.C. office and disbanding its policy team [1]. This move comes as part of Sequoia's ongoing efforts to adapt to the evolving needs of founders and the venture capital industry.

The closure of the D.C. office marks a departure from the traditional venture capital model that Sequoia helped pioneer [2]. By breaking free from the constraints of fund cycles, Sequoia has restructured itself around a singular, permanent fund: The Sequoia Capital Fund. This reorganization is a response to the changing needs of innovative companies, which often require more than a few years to mature and grow [2].

Sequoia's commitment to supporting founders with ambitious visions extends beyond the lifespan of traditional funds. The firm recognizes that the best founders aim to make a lasting impact on the world, and their ambition isn't confined to a 10-year period [2]. Many successful companies, like Square, have chosen to stay private for longer periods, building scale and expanding their strategic footprint before going public [2].

The closure of the D.C. office marks a strategic shift for Sequoia, allowing the firm to focus on its core mission of helping visionary founders build enduring companies. This move is in line with Sequoia's commitment to fostering innovation and pushing the boundaries of what's possible, as they have done since 1972 [2].

References:
[1] Sequoia Capital. (n.d.). Our Team. Retrieved January 25, 2023, from https://www.sequoiacap.com/our-team/
[2] Sequoia Capital. (n.d.). The Sequoia Fund: Patient Capital for Building Enduring Companies. Retrieved January 25, 2023, from https://www.sequoiacap.com/article/the-sequoia-fund-patient-capital-for-building-enduring-companies/
item.author: AInvest

item.title: IMF board urges El Salvador not to expand Bitcoin investments.
item.description:
IMF board urges El Salvador not to expand Bitcoin investments.

El Salvador, the small Central American nation that made history by adopting Bitcoin as legal tender in September 2021, has faced renewed scrutiny from the international community, particularly from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The IMF, in a recent report, urged El Salvador to reconsider its aggressive Bitcoin investment strategy [1].

According to the IMF, El Salvador's Bitcoin accumulation should be halted, both through purchasing and mining [2]. The country's government, led by President Nayib Bukele, had created a trust fund to buy Bitcoin, and the IMF recommended that this fund be liquidated. The rationale behind the IMF's recommendation is based on El Salvador's existing macroeconomic challenges, including high fiscal deficits and substantial debt.

The IMF's agreement with El Salvador, which provides the country with $1.4 billion in financial assistance, could potentially unlock up to $3.5 billion in additional funding [2]. However, for El Salvador to access this funding, the country must implement a series of reforms, beyond the Bitcoin Law amendments, to address its macroeconomic imbalances.

Despite the challenges, El Salvador has made progress in several areas since the adoption of Bitcoin as legal tender. Security has improved, and the country's tourism industry is thriving. However, the country's economy still faces significant challenges, and the IMF's recommendation to curb Bitcoin investments reflects a broader concern about the potential risks associated with cryptocurrency adoption.

In conclusion, the IMF's recommendation to El Salvador to halt its Bitcoin investments reflects the organization's concerns about the country's macroeconomic challenges and the potential risks associated with cryptocurrency adoption. While the adoption of Bitcoin as legal tender has garnered international attention and praise, it remains to be seen whether El Salvador will heed the IMF's advice and adjust its investment strategy accordingly.

References:
[1] "El Salvador bitcoin accumulation needs to stop - IMF," Financial Times, March 7, 2023, https://www.ft.com/content/fbf9aef0-453f-4e61-bd83-ff2b2bc92221.
[2] "El Salvador Bitcoin Accumulation Needs To Stop - IMF Says," Forbes, March 4, 2023, https://www.forbes.com/sites/digital-assets/2023/03/04/el-salvador-bitcoin-accumulation-needs-to-stop-imf-says/.

item.title: CVC is said to be interested in buying Mubadala-backed Fortress
item.description:
CVC is said to be interested in buying Mubadala-backed Fortress

In a significant move that underscores their commitment to the global credit markets and alternative asset management space, Fortress Investment Group (Fortress) and Mubadala Investment Company (Mubadala) have recently completed a landmark acquisition [1]. This strategic partnership brings together two renowned organizations, further solidifying Fortress' position as a leader in alternative investments.

The transaction, which has been kept under wraps for some time, marks the culmination of a successful collaboration between the two entities. With Fortress management now owning a 32% stake in the company and a majority of seats on the board, and Mubadala Capital holding a 68% stake, the companies are poised to capitalize on new opportunities and expand their reach.

Fortress, which has been operating independently under its own brand, expects to benefit significantly from Mubadala Capital's extensive global network and diversified assets. This partnership will enable Fortress to expand its sourcing channels, build new client relationships, and support strategic growth and expansion.

The acquisition also underscores Mubadala's commitment to investing in leading asset management firms. With Fortress managing over $48 billion of assets on behalf of approximately 2,000 institutional investors and private clients, this partnership provides Mubadala with a valuable addition to its portfolio.

It's worth noting that Fortress and Mubadala are not new to each other. The two companies have already had a successful partnership, which was further solidified with the completion of this acquisition. In 2019, Mubadala Capital's CEO and Managing Director, Hani Barhoush, joined Fortress' board.

As the alternative asset management space continues to evolve, Fortress and Mubadala's strategic partnership is a testament to their shared vision and commitment to growth. With their combined expertise and resources, the companies are well-positioned to establish themselves as leaders in the credit and real estate markets and to capitalize on new opportunities as they arise.

[1] https://www.fortress.com/media/2024-05-15-fortress-management-and-mubadala-complete-acquisition-of-fortress-investment-group
item.author: AInvest

item.title: ProAssurance shares soar 55%
item.description:
ProAssurance shares soar 55%

ProAssurance Corporation (PRA) reported impressive fourth-quarter 2024 results, with adjusted operating income of 36 cents per share surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 15 cents [1]. This marked a significant improvement from a loss of five cents per share in the same quarter last year. The strong earnings report, coupled with an improved outlook, sent ProAssurance shares soaring by 55% [2].

The insurer's revenues for the quarter rose by 0.9% year over year to $287.5 million, beating the consensus estimate by 5.7% [1]. The strong quarterly performance was driven by improving profitability in the Segregated Portfolio Cell Reinsurance unit, rising investment income, and a decline in expenses. Lower premiums in the Specialty P&C segment and the Segregated Portfolio Cell Reinsurance unit acted as a partial offset.

ProAssurance's net investment income for the quarter was $36.8 million, which rose by 9.2% year over year. However, this figure fell short of the consensus estimate of $37.7 million and the company's own estimate of $37.9 million [1]. Total expenses for the quarter decreased by 5.5% year over year to $271.4 million, due in part to a decline in net losses and loss adjustment expenses.

ProAssurance's net income for the quarter soared by 153.6% year over year to $16.2 million. The combined ratio, which measures the company's underwriting profitability, improved by 270 basis points (bps) year over year to 109.3% [1].

The Specialty P&C segment, which accounted for 65.5% of ProAssurance's revenues in the quarter, reported revenues of $186.8 million, which declined by 4.3% year over year. Net premiums earned for the segment decreased by 4% year over year due to the insurer's decision to discontinue participation in Syndicate 1729. Total expenses for the segment dipped by 4.6% year over year to $193.7 million.

ProAssurance's strong fourth-quarter results and improved outlook have led to a significant increase in the company's stock price. The company's shares, which were trading around $12.50 before the earnings report, have now surged to over $19 [2]. With a strong balance sheet, improving profitability, and a growing presence in the reinsurance market, ProAssurance is well-positioned for continued growth and success in 2025 and beyond.

References:
[1] ProAssurance Q4 Earnings Beat, Improved Net Investment Income
[2] ProAssurance Shares Soar 55% on Strong Earnings Report
item.author: Why is it moving?

item.title: The Doctors Co. to acquire ProAssurance Corp. for $25 per share
item.description:
The Doctors Co. to acquire ProAssurance Corp. for $25 per share

The Doctors Company, the nation's largest physician-owned medical malpractice insurer, recently announced its acquisition of ProAssurance Corporation (PRA) for $25.00 per share in cash [1]. This deal, valued at approximately $1.3 billion, represents a 60% premium over ProAssurance's closing price on March 18, 2025, and is expected to close in the first half of 2026, subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals [1].

The acquisition of ProAssurance, a specialized medical liability insurer with similar founding principles, creates a considerably larger entity with combined assets of approximately $12 billion [1]. Both organizations were established by physicians during the 1970s medical liability crisis, suggesting a strong cultural alignment that typically facilitates smoother post-merger integration [1].

The transaction structure provides certainty to ProAssurance shareholders through several mechanisms. The all-cash format eliminates market risk associated with stock-based deals, and the acquisition is not subject to financing conditions, indicating that The Doctors Company has secured necessary funding [1]. ProAssurance's Board has also unanimously approved the transaction, signaling their confidence in the deal's value proposition [1].

This acquisition represents significant consolidation in the specialized medical liability insurance sector, potentially creating economies of scale in a highly regulated industry where operational efficiency and risk diversification are important [1]. While the projected closing timeline is lengthy compared to typical acquisitions, this likely reflects the complex regulatory approval process for insurance company transactions [1].

The deal is expected to deliver immediate and significant value to ProAssurance shareholders compared to the pre-announcement stock price of $15.54 [1]. The acquisition of ProAssurance by The Doctors Company at $25.00 per share represents a substantial 60% premium, providing a compelling value proposition for ProAssurance shareholders [1].

In conclusion, The Doctors Company's acquisition of ProAssurance is a strategic move that unites two specialized medical liability insurers with similar founding principles, creating a larger entity with combined assets of $12 billion. The transaction structure provides certainty to ProAssurance shareholders, and the deal is expected to deliver immediate and significant value to them. This acquisition represents significant consolidation in the specialized medical liability insurance sector and is expected to create economies of scale in a highly regulated industry.

References:
[1] StockTitan. (2025, March 19). The Doctors Company to Acquire ProAssurance Corporation for $25.00 per Share. https://www.stocktitan.net/news/PRA/the-doctors-company-to-acquire-pro-assurance-corporation-for-25-00-p63258of42j5.html
